Sure, here is an example program in Python to find the median of a set of numbers:

```
numbers = [5, 2, 8, 3, 9, 1, 4, 7, 6]

# First, sort the list of numbers
numbers.sort()

# Find the middle index of the list
middle_index = len(numbers) // 2

# If the list has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle element
if len(numbers) % 2 == 1:
    median = numbers[middle_index]

# If the list has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle two elements
else:
    median = (numbers[middle_index - 1] + numbers[middle_index]) / 2

print("The median is:", median)
```

In this example, the list of numbers is `[5, 2, 8, 3, 9, 1, 4, 7, 6]`. The program first sorts the list using the `sort()` method. Then, it finds the middle index of the list using integer division (`//`). If the list has an odd number of elements, the median is simply the middle element. If the list has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle two elements. Finally, the program prints the median value to the console.
